source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_044_chunk2
evidence_span: Specimens were hydrided gaseously at 400°C to prescribed levels between 50 and 750 μg/g

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_044_chunk2
evidence_span: strips of flattened tubing were stressed in the circumferential direction to greater than 250 MPa

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_044_chunk2
evidence_span: A set of 40 flat, compact specimens of cold-worked (c.w.) Zr-2.5Nb were irradiated for one year in the WR-1 reactor at WNRE. This reactor is cooled by an organic fluid, yielding an irradiation temperature of 350°C

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_044_chunk2
evidence_span: A second set of specimens was therefore irradiated for nine months at 262°C in the NRU reactor at Chalk River Nuclear Laboratories (CRNL)

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_044_chunk2
evidence_span: Both sets of specimens contained subsets that were hydrided to a level of 200 μg/g (circumferential hydrides)

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_044_chunk2
evidence_span: Compact specimens were cut from strips of flattened tubing containing 90 μg/g of hydrogen precipitated in the radial orientation

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_044_chunk2
evidence_span: Part of this set of specimens was irradiated for six months in the NRU reactor

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_044_chunk2
evidence_span: Most of those specimens were irradiated at 39°C to prevent any thermally induced changes in hydride morphology

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_044_chunk2
evidence_span: The rest were irradiated at 262°C, a typical CANDU reactor operating temperature

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_044_chunk2
evidence_span: Thicknesses were 3.7 to 4.7 mm

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_044_chunk3
evidence_span: Sixteen curved compact specimens were spark machined from the failed P2-G16 pressure tube and tested as part of the failure analysis program. These contained hydrides, in concentrations ranging from 42 to 146 μg/g, in mixed orientations (i.e., both circumferential and radial hydrides were present)

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_044_chunk3
evidence_span: Specimens were tested at temperatures ranging from 25 to 300°C in servohydraulic machines at a displacement rate of 0.25 mm/min

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_044_chunk3
evidence_span: Specimens were tested at temperatures ranging from 25 to 300°C in servohydraulic machines at a displacement rate of 0.25 mm/min

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_044_chunk3
evidence_span: Brittle behavior was observed for two conditions. Some specimens containing 100 μg/g or more circumferential hydride, and tested at 25°C, failed in this manner

evidence_span: Brittle behavior was observed for two conditions. Some specimens containing 100 μg/g or more circumferential hydride, and tested at 25°C, failed in this manner

evidence_span: Figure 7 shows some typical J_R curves for c.w. Zr-2.5Nb tested at 240°C

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_044_chunk4
evidence_span: Curve 1 represents c.w. Zr-2.5Nb in the as-received condition (i.e., unirradiated and having a nominal (NOM) hydrogen concentration between 7 and 15 μg/g)
specimen_state: c.w., as-received, unirradiated, hydrogen concentration 7-15 μg/g

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_044_chunk4
evidence_span: Curve 2, which is nearly identical to Curve 1, represents two specimens containing 200 μg/g of radial (R) hydride and tested at 270°C to ensure that they were on the upper shelf of the ductile-brittle transition (DBT)

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_044_chunk4
evidence_span: Irradiation at 350°C had a small, but measurable, effect on the J_R curve at 240°C, as shown by Curve 3

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_044_chunk4
evidence_span: circumferential (C) hydride had a further small, but measurable effect, on toughness (Curve 4)

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_044_chunk4
evidence_span: Irradiation at 262°C has a much stronger effect on the J_R curve than irradiation at 350°C, as shown by Curves 5 and 6, which attain steady-state J_R values below 200 kJ/m²

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_044_chunk7
evidence_span: strengthening factors, such as reduction in temperature, irradiation, and cold work, all lead to significant reductions in ductility

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_044_chunk7
evidence_span: Irradiation does not have a measurable effect on the ductile-brittle transition temperature

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_044_chunk7
evidence_span: Circumferential hydride has a measurable, deleterious effect on fracture toughness, even above the temperatures at which fracture occurs under the transverse stress field of the approaching crack

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_044_chunk8
evidence_span: An experimental program undertaken by CEA, EDF, and FRAGEMA with the aim of characterizing the fatigue and creep-fatigue behavior of Zircaloy-4 following different annealing treatments (recrystallization, stress relief, etc.) is in progress. The results given in this paper concern only recrystallized material.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_044_chunk8
evidence_span: Low-cycle fatigue curves and creep behavior laws under high stresses have been established.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_044_chunk8
evidence_span: Sequential tests of pure fatigue and creep-fatigue were performed.
